title: Dave Bartholomew
description:
Dave Bartholomew 

Born 24 December 1920, Edgard, Louisiana, United States of America) is a musician, band leader, composer, and arranger, prominent in the music of New Orleans throughout the second half of the 20th century.

Bartholomew helped develop and define the New Orleans sound which was so influential in the 1950s. He was key in the transition from jump blues and big-band swing to rhythm and blues and rock and roll.[3]

Bartholomew and Domino co-wrote many songs that were hits, including "Ain&#039;t That a Shame", "I&#039;m in Love Again" "Blue Monday" and "I&#039;m Walkin&#039;".

His "I Hear You Knocking" was a hit for Gale Storm in the 50&#039;s, and Dave Edmunds in the 70&#039;s; "One Night" and "Witchcraft" were both hits for Elvis Presley. Pat Boone&#039;s cover of "AinÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢t That a Shame," and Rick Nelson&#039;s version of "I&#039;m Walkin&#039;" were top twenty hits in the late &#039;50s and early &#039;60s. Chuck Berry&#039;s only #1 Hot 100 hit was a cover of Bartholomew&#039;s "My Ding-a-Ling", although Berry substantially changed the arrangement and verses.

Bartholomew produced a series of memorable hits such as "Lawdy Miss Clawdy" with Lloyd Price; and "I Hear You Knocking" and "One Night" with Smiley Lewis; plus "Let the Good Times Roll" with Shirley & Lee.
